title: 103_hr103
content:
The "Fair and Competitive Election Act" is the short title of the Act. It includes a limitation on contributions to House of Representatives elections from individuals who are not local residents. The "Fair and Competitive Election Act" amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to limit contributions to House of Representatives candidates from non-local residents. Candidates exceeding the limit must refund or pay penalties based on the excess contributions. The "Fair and Competitive Election Act" imposes penalties on candidates who accept contributions exceeding the set limits. Those exceeding the limit by 5-10% must pay three times the excess amount to the Commission. Candidates exceeding the limit by 10% or more must pay three times the excess amount plus a civil penalty determined by the Commission. Additionally, individuals cannot be considered residents of more than one congressional district for the purposes of this Act. SEC. 3. REDUCTION IN LIMITATION AMOUNT FOR NONPARTY MULTICANDIDATE POLITICAL COMMITTEE CONTRIBUTIONS TO CANDIDATES. No nonparty multicandidate political committee may exceed $1,000 in contributions. Technical amendment made to Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971.

SEC. 4. BAN ON SOFT MONEY. Title III of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 amended to include limitations and reporting requirements for amounts paid for mixed political activities. Sec. 323 imposes limitations and reporting requirements on payments for mixed political activities by national or state political party committees. The term 'mixed political activity' refers to activities aimed at influencing federal elections and unrelated purposes. Additionally, Section 301(8)(B) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to remove the building fund exception from the definition of 'contribution'. Transition rule regarding excess funds of House of Representatives candidates. A candidate running for Congress with excess campaign funds must deposit the surplus in a separate account. These funds can be used for lawful purposes other than the candidate's election campaign. Excess funds are those exceeding twice the amount raised from local individual residents after December 31, 1992. Until the 1994 pre-primary report, the candidate can transfer excess funds back to the campaign account if the majority of contributions were from local residents. No funds can be transferred from the separate account to a campaign account. Candidates running for Congress with excess campaign funds must deposit the surplus in a separate account. These funds can be used for lawful purposes other than the candidate's election campaign. Excess funds are those exceeding twice the amount raised from local individual residents after December 31, 1992. No funds may be transferred from a separate account to a campaign account after the 1994 pre-primary report. The amendments made by this Act will be effective on the date of enactment.
